Please remember to follow those principles, among others:
ADP: Acyclic Dependencies Principle The dependency structure between packages must not contain cyclic dependencies. http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?AcyclicDependenciesPrinciple
SDP: Stable Dependencies Principle The dependencies between packages should be in the direction of the stability of the packages. A package should only depend upon packages that are more stable than it is. http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?StableDependenciesPrinciple
SAP: Stable Abstractions Principle Packages that are maximally stable should be maximally abstract. Unstable packages should be concrete. The abstractness of a package should be in proportion to its stability. http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?StableAbstractionsPrinciple

section.title: Data Access Layer
section.para: The Data Access Object pattern is a strategy for constructing a single API which encapsulates all data fetching operations (such as SQL queries), allowing our application logic to be a client to that API without needing to be concerned with SQL syntax.

The Data Access Object pattern provides a useful way to abstract data fetching operations. Here, the implementation is simple, however it is sufficient to add a layer of abstraction to seperate our application logic from the underlying database.

listitem.simpara: The class DataAccess deals with connecting to MySQL and performing functions like mysql_query().
DataAccess returns an instance of the DataAccessResult class, which we can use to fetch rows from the query.

DataAcessObject class provides only two methods, the first for retrieving data (SELECT statement) which will return the instance for DataAccessResult from the DataAccess class. The second method is used for anything that changes the database, i.e. INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE.

section.title: What is priority ?
section.para: EventManager fire events to listeners. The order depends on listener's priority.
Between two listeners A and B, if priorities are equal, there is no specific order. Maybe FIFO, however it depends on implementation.
If priority of A is bigger than priority of B (A.priority > B.priority) then A is waked up before B.

section.title: Naming Convention
section.para: The short-name of a plugin must be unique and composed of lowercase letters only, because it is going to be used in table names and we don't want namespace conflicts.
The main class of the plugin must be composed of the short-name followed by "Plugin.class" e.g: "templatePlugin.class".

section.title: Plugin Directory Structure
section.para:
In plugins/template/:
cgi-bin: cgi scripts. Contains cgi used by the plugin. It will be accessible by the following URI: http://example.com/plugins/template/cgi-bin/, db: database scripts. Contains among others install.sql and uninstall.sql (not mandatory), etc: scripts to configure/customize the plugin. The directory will be copied in /etc/codex/plugins/template/etc, include: contains PHP classes, including the main class of the plugin, site-content: the repository for plugin specific text and messages. This can be customized with /etc/codex/plugins/template/site-content/, www: web space of the plugin. It will be accessible by the following URI: http://example.com/plugins/template/. It is useful for images, html or php pages, etc. specific to the plugin.

section.title: What is a hook ?
section.para: A hook is an event. The aim of a hook is to allow plugins to do a specific action when a part of the CodeX core is reached.

section.title: How to listen/subscribe to a hook ?
section.para: In your plugin constructor just add $this->addHook('name_of_hook'); foreach hooks you want to listen to.

section.title: How to respond to a hook ?
section.para: Plugins responds to hooks with callbacks. A callback is a method of the class of your plugin. The default callback is CallHook wich takes two parameters : the name of the hook fired and the parameters in an array.

If you want your plugin to respond to a hook with another callback (to prevent many ifs or switches in one callback), you have to say it during subscription: $this->_addHook('name_of_hook', 'specific_callback', $recall_hook = false/true);. The two additionnal parameters are : the name of the callback, and a boolean which indicates if you want to know which hook is fired (to treat different hooks in the same callback). The default values for those parameters are CallHook, true.
For a real example, see the plugin PluginsAdministration.

section.title: How to fire a hook ?
section.para: In the core of CodeX, since hooks are events, you fire them via the EventManager: $em->processEvent('the_hook', $params_of_hook);.
Important: the parameters is given to ALL plugins which listen to the hook.

section.title: How can I make a plugin respond to a hook before another plugin ?
section.para: Plugins are independant. Plugins developpers should not make predictions about the order of listeners of a hook.

However, administrators can ajust the priority between plugins for a hook. It is done in the PluginsAdministration page: for each hooks are listed the plugins and their priority. Ajust priority at the level you want. Priority is realized by an integer: plugins are waked up from higher to lower. Default priority is zero.

section.title: GForge Plugins
section.para: Since CodeX wants to make plugins as much closed as possible to GForge plugins, it is, in theory and relatively, possible to migrate a plugin from GForge to CodeX. You have to follow the following points:

listitem.simpara: Foreach hook, modify how plugin interacts with (parameters will be different in most cases)
Modify hard links
Make PostGres scripts "MySql compatible"
Move installation sql script in db/install.sql
Move uninstallation sql script in db/uninstall.sql

section.title: Install
section.para: First, you have to copy the plugin files in the plugins directory. Untar ou unzip the archive, cvs or svn checkout.
Second, you have to copy directories (etc, site-content) of the plugin in etc directory :
Finally, once these two steps are done, you have two way to finish the installation : manually or automatically.

section.title: Manually
section.para: You have to tell CodeX that you want to use this plugin. You do that by inserting a new row in the plugin table : INSERT INTO plugin (name, enabled) VALUES ('template', 0);. name is the short-name of the plugin. You have to set enabled to 1 if you want to enable the plugin.
If the plugins use the database, use the db/install.sql script to create/populate tables.

section.title: Automatically
section.para: With the plugin PluginsAdministration, you can manage your plugins through a web-based interface.
Locate your plugin in the 'not yet installed' plugins list and select it to install it. PluginsAdministration will update the database for you and will run db/install.sql during installation.
Note that the plugin will be disabled by default. You will have to enabled it (again with PluginsAdministration) after installation.
The plugin PluginsAdministration is part of CodeX.

listitem.simpara: First, all plugins which are enabled are loaded by the PluginManager. This is done before all things (session/themes/...) and therefore BaseLanguage is not yet loaded: you can't load directly message files in your plugin.
Then, when a point in the core of CodeX is reached, the EventManager fires an event to all listeners. A plugin may respond to this event (hook) as he wants (please remember that it is not alone !).

section.title: Uninstall
section.para: With the PluginsAdministration, you can simply uninstall a plugin: it will run db/uninstall.sql, delete priorities and remove the plugin from the plugin table.
If you don't use PluginsAdministration, you have to do those steps by hands.

Important: in both cases (manually, automatically) you may have to remove the directory of the plugin because its web space (/plugins/template/www/) will always remain accessible, even if the plugin is disabled or uninstalled.

section.title: Themes
section.para: Traditional themes like CodeX or Savannah inherit from Layout. Tabbed themes, like CodeXTab, inherit from TabbedLayout. And as GForge themes are tabbed, they inherit from GForgeLayout which inherit from TabbedLayout.

section.title: Cookbook to install a GForge Theme (gforge_theme) into CodeX
section.para: In order to make a GForge Theme 'CodeX compatible', you have to follow those steps :

listitem.simpara: Copy the theme in themes directory: cp -r /path/to/your/gforge_theme /etc/codex/themes/.
Rename your Theme.class file : mv /etc/codex/themes/gforge_theme/Theme.class /etc/codex/themes/gforge_theme/gforge_theme_Theme.class
(Rename also your Theme class)
This is to prevent from name clash with other Theme class, like with PhpWiki.
Make Theme class inherit from GForgeLayout, don't forget to include it.
Change html_image calls: put width and height in the array parameter
Replace session_loggedin by user_isloggedin
Check if footer calls generic_footer (This will replace GForge copyright by CodeX copyright)
Replace the GForge logo by a CodeX logo
Copy CodeX images cp -ir /home/httpd/SF/www/themes/CodeX/images/* /etc/codex/themes/gforge_theme/images/. (Say no for each prompt)
Remove trailing spaces in the Theme class file (To prevent sending characters before headers)
Update css with missing rules (most of them are in GForgeLayout::header)
Put missing languages strings in themes/gforge-compat.tab
Be careful with images and css paths: themes in /etc are accessible via /custom/gforge_theme/ (Fix $imgroot for exemple)
